0.title: What is Kittykeys?
0.content: Kittykeys is a programmable, fully customizable plugin that implements event-driven architecture. A producer creates an event that is caused by change or update, that triggers routing which finally leads to consumer to take action. This means that you can run set of commands when you press a hotkey or automate it to happen when something happens in-game.

1.title: Features
1.content: . | Configurable click locations (random/constant) | Configurable delays (random/instant) | Option to turn mouse clicks off | Option to allow multiple scripts to run at same time | Option to queue any pending scripts that may try to run while another is already running | Option to force stop all running scripts | Option to block hotkeys from chat | Option to disable timeouts when using trigger (event) inside command | Tab autocompletion for command and trigger names. | . Miscellaneous features: . | Permanent special attack bar | .

2.title: How Kittykeys Works
2.content: The general event flow is: Producer → routing → consumer .

3.title: Examples
3.content: Enable protect from melee by pressing key A: . Key press → key matches a bound hotkey → run script (enable protect from melee) . Drop logs when inventory gets full: . Inventory full → matching script with this trigger was found → run script (drop all logs from inventory) .

5.title: ANIMATION_ANY
5.content: When any nearby player or NPC performs the specified animation, this trigger is hit.

6.title: Syntax
6.content: ANIMATION_ANY Animation_ID . | Animation_ID : The integer ID of an animation. | .

7.title: Examples
7.content: // Pray magic against Jad in the inferno Jad challenge ANIMATION_ANY 7592 // Commands Sleep 600 700 PROTECT_FROM_MAGIC 1 .

10.title: ANIMATION_SELF
10.content: When the specified animation starts on the player, this trigger is hit.

11.title: Syntax
11.content: ANIMATION_SELF Animation_ID . | Animation_ID : The integer ID of an animation. | .

12.title: Examples
12.content: // Trigger when the player digs with a spade ANIMATION_SELF 830 .

13.title: Notes
13.content: . | To find an animation ID, use Kittykeys -> Settings -> Print events to chat. Animation IDs are also shown with Dev tools -> Players or NPCs (if using dev tools, A holds the current animation ID). | .

15.title: ANIMATION_TARGET
15.content: When the specified animation starts on the current TARGET player or NPC, this trigger is hit.

16.title: Syntax
16.content: ANIMATION_TARGET Animation_ID . | Animation_ID : The integer ID of an animation. | .

18.title: Notes
18.content: . | If the player does not have a target, this command will do nothing. See the TARGET_SET command for more information. | You can find an animation ID by using Kittykeys -> Settings -> Print events to chat, or by using Dev tools -> Player or NPCs (if using dev tools, A holds the current animation ID). | .

21.title: Syntax
21.content: BANK_WIELD Item_Name_1|Item_ID_1[,Item_Name_2|Item_ID_2,...] . | Item_Name : The string name of an item. When specifying items by name, use underscores instead of spaces, and do not use quotes; in this mode, you can also use asterisks as wildcards | Item_ID : The integer ID of an item. | .

23.title: Notes
23.content: . | Generally, you should prefer items’ integer IDs, as they are more precise. However, in certain situations, using the item’s name with a wildcard is required. | .

25.title: Commands in Kittykeys
25.content: Commands are the heart of all scripts, they are the instructions that tell a script what to do next. Kittykeys supports the following commands as documented below. If you have any questions, please join the JumpIfZero Plugins Discord server, and we’ll be happy to help! .

26.title: Supported Commands
26.content: As of version 1.7.2, Kittykeys supports the following commands: .

27.title: Commands
27.content: Hey, Listen! . This wiki is not complete (yet). Please refer to the Help tab in the Kittykeys Editor, or to the JZ Plugins Discord server, for the most up-to-date information.

28.title: CONSUME
28.content: Clicks on the first occurrence of the inventory item(s).

29.title: Syntax
29.content: CONSUME Item_Name_1|Item_ID_1[,Item_Name_2|Item_ID_2,...] [Identifier] . | Item_Name : The string name of an item. When specifying items by name, use underscores instead of spaces, and do not use quotes; in this mode, you can also use asterisks as wildcards. | Item_ID : The integer ID of an item. | Multiple Items (Optional) : To specify multiple items, separate each with a comma and no space. | Identifier (Optional) : The integer value Identifier can be used with a single item if the desired action is not the default action for that item (i.e., if it is not the left-click action). | . TODO: How to locate Identifier .

30.title: Examples
30.content: // Consume (click) the first occurrence of anything with "cake" somewhere in the name CONSUME *cake* // Guzzle the Dwarven rock cake. "Guzzle" has an Identifier of 4 CONSUME Dwarven_Rock_cake 4 // This is equivalent, it also guzzles the Dwarven rock cake CONSUME *Rock_cake 4 .

31.title: Notes
31.content: . | If you specify multiple items, they will all be consumed within one game tick. | OSRS limits players to 10 actions per each tick. | Generally, you should prefer items’ integer IDs, as they are more precise. However, in certain situations, a wildcard is required. When consuming potions or multiple food items, use the names: | . // GOOD: Consume the first available Sara brew (any dose) CONSUME Saradomin_brew* // GOOD: Triple eat in a single game tick CONSUME Shark,Saradomin_brew*,*karambwan* // BAD: Using the ID for Saradomin Brew(4) would ignore any 3-, 2-, or 1-dose brews. CONSUME 6685 .

33.title: CONSUME_ALL
33.content: Clicks once on each occurrence of the specified inventory item(s).

34.title: Syntax
34.content: CONSUME_ALL Item_Name_1|Item_ID_1[,Item_Name_2|Item_ID_2,...] [Identifier] . | Item_Name : The string name of an item. When specifying items by name, use underscores instead of spaces, and do not use quotes; in this mode, you can also use asterisks as wildcards | Item_ID : The integer ID of an item. | Multiple Items (Optional) : To specify multiple items, separate each with a comma and no space. | Identifier (Optional) : The integer value Identifier can be used with a single item if the desired action is not the default action for that item (i.e., if it is not the left-click action). | . TODO: How to locate the Identifier .

35.title: Examples
35.content: // Drop all logs in the inventory. 7 is the Identifier for "drop". CONSUME_ALL *logs* 7 .

36.title: Notes
36.content: . | If you specify multiple items, they will all be consumed within one game tick. | OSRS limits players to 10 actions per each tick. | Generally, you should prefer items’ integer IDs, as they are more precise. However, in certain situations, using the item’s name with a wildcard is required. | .

38.title: CUSTOM
38.content: Performs any action, even actions that are not natively supported by an exsisting command.

40.title: Examples
40.content: I want to toggle run, but there’s no RUN command! . | Switch to the Game chat tab in OSRS | Go to Kittykeys → Settings → Debug | Enable Print clicks to chat | Perform the desired action, and see which numbers Kittykeys prints to Game chat | (Optional) Disable Print clicks to chat to keep the chatbox clean | Enter every number as a parameter to the custom command | .

42.title: Notes
42.content: . | Every number printed for a given click is required. Separate each number with one space. | . CUSTOM will not work for actions where the identifiers or parameters will change, including any click on game objects, or if an inventory item moves to a different slot. For actions that have have their own command (e.g., OBJECT or CONSUME), use the dedicated command instead.

43.title: DEATH
43.content: When the player dies, this trigger is hit.

44.title: Syntax
44.content: DEATH . | This trigger takes no arguments. | .

48.title: EMOTE
48.content: Performs the emote with the specified name.

49.title: Syntax
49.content: EMOTE Emote_Name . | Emote_Name : The name of an emote to perform. When specifying an emote, use underscores instead of spaces, and do not use quotes. | .

50.title: Examples
50.content: // Dance like no one's watching EMOTE Dance // Show off your skillcape (does nothing if a skillcape is not equipped) EMOTE Skill_Cape .

51.title: Notes
51.content: . | Only specify one emote per command. // BAD: One command won't perform multiple emotes EMOTE Dance,Bow // GOOD: Use separate commands to perform a sequence of emotes EMOTE Dance EMOTE Bow . | .

53.title: GAME_OBJECT_SPAWN
53.content: When game object spawns, this trigger is hit.

57.title: GRAPHIC_SELF
57.content: Triggers when the specified graphic is rendered on the player.

59.title: Examples
59.content: // Graphic 264 is used when the player cast blooms with a silver sickle (b) GRAPHIC_SELF 264 .

60.title: Notes
60.content: . | You can find an ID by using Kittykeys -> Settings -> Print events to chat, or by using Dev tools -> Player (if using dev tools, G holds the current graphic ID). | .

62.title: GRAPHIC_SPAWN
62.content: When the specified graphic spawns nearby, this trigger is hit.

63.title: Syntax
63.content: GRAPHIC_SPAWN Graphic_ID . | Graphic_ID : The integer ID of a graphic. | .

64.title: Examples
64.content: // Ice Barage was cast on another player nearby GRAPHIC_SPAWN 369 . TODO: Other Examples .

65.title: Notes
65.content: . | Although dev Tools is required to find specific IDs (graphic or animation), graphics are “external” to the player in most cases: . | Someone casting aspell on the player (e.g., ice barrage). | An item adding something, such as Bloom cast with a silver sickle (b). | . | The RuneLite API documents a partial list of graphics in Graphic_ID.java. | .

67.title: GRAPHIC_TARGET
67.content: Triggers when the specified graphic is rendered on the current target.

69.title: Examples
69.content: // Graphic 264 is used when the player casts bloom with a silver sickle (b) GRAPHIC_TARGET 264 .

70.title: Notes
70.content: . | You can find an ID by using Kittykeys -> Settings -> Print events to chat, or by using Dev tools -> NPC or Player (if using dev tools, G holds the current graphic ID). | .

72.title: HITSPLAT
72.content: Triggers when a hitsplat lands on the player’s current target.

73.title: Syntax
73.content: HITSPLAT [Min_Value] . | Min_Value (Optional) : Only trigger when a hitsplat higher than the specified value lands on the target. If no value is specified, all hits (not 0) will activate the trigger. | .

74.title: Examples
74.content: // Activate if any hitsplat lands on the target, except 0 HITSPLAT // Activate only if a hitsplat of 5 or greater lands on the target HITSPLAT 5 .

75.title: Notes
75.content: . | The type of hitsplat (poison, venom, normal damage) does not matter. | .

77.title: IDLE
77.content: When the player returns to idle, this trigger is hit.

78.title: Syntax
78.content: IDLE [minMS] [maxMS] . | minMS : When one or two values are supplied, this is the exact or minimum number of milliseconds that the player will be idle before the trigger activates. | maxMS : When two values are supplied, this is the maximum number of milliseconds that the player will be idle before the trigger activates. A random number between minMS and MaxMS is selected for the trigger delay. | .

79.title: INTERACTION_END
79.content: When player interaction ends (returns to null), this trigger is hit.

80.title: Syntax
80.content: INTERACTION_END . | This trigger takes no arguments. | .

81.title: INVENTORY_EMPTY
81.content: When the player’s inventory becomes empty, this trigger is hit.

82.title: Syntax
82.content: INVENTORY_EMPTY . | This trigger takes no arguments. | .

83.title: Notes
83.content: . | Useful for various skilling and bankstanding. | .

84.title: INVENTORY_FULL
84.content: When the player’s inventory becomes full, this trigger is hit.

85.title: Syntax
85.content: INVENTORY_FULL . | This trigger takes no arguments. | .

86.title: Notes
86.content: . | Useful for various skilling and bankstanding. | .

88.title: ITEM_NPC
88.content: Uses the first occurrence of an inventory item on your NPC target.

89.title: Syntax
89.content: ITEM_NPC Item_Name|Item_ID . | Item_Name : The string name of an item. When specifying items by name, use underscores instead of spaces, and do not use quotes; in this mode, you can also use asterisks as wildcards | Item_ID : The integer ID of an item. | .

90.title: Examples
90.content: // Use noted bowstrings (1778) on the current target NPC ITEM_NPC 1778 .

91.title: Notes
91.content: . | If the player does not have a target, this command will do nothing. See TARGET_SET for more information. | Generally, you should prefer items’ integer IDs, as they are more precise. However, in certain situations, using the item’s name with a wildcard is required. | .

93.title: ITEM_SPAWN
93.content: When item spawns on ground, this trigger is hit. , or using dev tools > ground items and getting the itemID from it.

94.title: Syntax
94.content: ITEM_SPAWN ItemID . | Item_ID : The integer ID of an item. | .

96.title: Notes
96.content: . | Lookup item IDs by using Print events to chat in Kittykeys Settings, or by using Dev Tools -> Ground Items | Find item IDs online: https://chinplugins.xyz/items | .

97.title: ITEM_USE
97.content: Combines the first occurrence of inventory item 1 with the first occurrence of inventory item.

98.title: Syntax
98.content: ITEM_USE Item_Name_1|Item_ID_1 Item_Name_2|Item_ID_2 . | Item_Name : The string name of an item. When specifying items by name, use underscores instead of spaces, and do not use quotes; in this mode, you can also use asterisks as wildcards | Item_ID : The integer ID of an item. | .

99.title: Examples
99.content: // Attach a stack of feathers to a stack of dart tips (any type) ITEM_USE Feather *Dart_tip* // This example specifically uses a feather on Adamant dart tips. // Remember: All integer IDs are unique! ITEM_USE Feather 823 .

100.title: Notes:
100.content: . | Generally, you should prefer items’ integer IDs, as they are more precise. However, in certain situations, using the item’s name with a wildcard is required. | .

102.title: MOVE
102.content: Moves the player in a straight line, relative to the player’s current position.

104.title: Examples
104.content: // Move one tile up and one tile to the right MOVE -1 -1 // Move six tiles down and one tile to the left MOVE 6 1 // Move nine tiles to the right MOVE 0 -9 .

105.title: Notes
105.content: . | MOVE is best used over short distances, such as to step away from an area-of-effect (AOE) attack. For longer distances, consider using the SCENE_WALK command. | The player’s current position is treated as (0,0) on an invisible grid of world tiles. All movements are specified as n tiles away from wherever the player is already standing on the X and Y axes. | Positive X is Right. Negative X is Left. | Negative Y is Down. Positive Y is Up. | An X or Y value of 0 means “do not move” (left/right or up/down) | . | .

107.title: NPC_DESPAWN
107.content: When the specified NPC despawns nearby, this trigger is hit.

108.title: Syntax
108.content: NPC_DESPAWN NPC_Name|NPC_ID . | NPC_Name : The string name of an NPC. When specifying an NPC by name, use underscores instead of spaces, and do not use quotes; in this mode, you can also use asterisks as wildcards | NPC_ID : The integer ID of an NPC. | .

110.title: Notes
110.content: . | If more than one of the same NPC are nearby, matches the closest NPC to the player. | .

112.title: NPC_SPAWN
112.content: When the specified NPC spawn snearby, this trigger is hit.

113.title: Syntax
113.content: NPC_SPAWN NPC_Name|NPC_ID . | NPC_Name : The string name of an NPC. When specifying an NPC by name, use underscores instead of spaces, and do not use quotes; in this mode, you can also use asterisks as wildcards | NPC_ID : The integer ID of an NPC. | .

115.title: Notes
115.content: . | Find NPC IDs using Dev Tools -> NPCs | Used with SET_TARGET for other commands | .

117.title: OBJECT
117.content: Clicks on the first instance of the specified game object, decoration object, or wall object nearby.

118.title: Syntax
118.content: OBJECT Object_ID [MenuAction] . | MenuAction (Optional) : The integer value MenuAction can be if the desired action is not the default action for that object (i.e., if it is not the left-click action). | .

119.title: Examples
119.content: // TODO: Examples // Game object (use Dev tools -> Objects) OBJECT 12308 // Wall object (Use Dev tools -> Walls) OBJECT *vein* .

122.title: OVERHEAD
122.content: When target overhead changes, this trigger is hit.

123.title: Syntax
123.content: OVERHEAD Overheadname . | OVERHEAD_NAME : The string name of an overhead. When specifying an overhead by name, use UPPERCASE with underscores instead of spaces, and do not use quotes. | .

125.title: Notes
125.content: . | Useful when making demonic gorilla swapper for example. | Possible values are: . | MELEE | RANGED | MAGIC | RETRIBUTION | SMITE | REDEMPTION | RANGE_MAGE | RANGE_MELEE | MAGE_MELEE | RANGE_MAGE_MELEE | WRATH | SOUL_SPLIT | DEFLECT_MELEE | DEFLECT_RANGE | DEFLECT_MAGE | . | .

127.title: PICKUP
127.content: Pick up an item from the ground.

128.title: Syntax
128.content: PICKUP [1] . | Use 1 to telegrab instead of picking up by walking. | .

132.title: PLAYER_DESPAWN
132.content: When a player with a matching namne despawns nearby, this trigger is hit.

133.title: Syntax
133.content: PLAYER_SPAWN Player_Name . | Player_Name : The string Display Name of any player. When specifying a player by name, use underscores instead of spaces, and do not use quotes; in this mode, you can also use asterisks as wildcards | .

134.title: Examples
134.content: // When any player despawns nearby PLAYER_DESPAWN * // When Sir_Pugger despawns nearby PLAYER_DESPAWN Sir_Pugger .

137.title: PLAYER_SPAWN
137.content: When a player with a matching namne spawns nearby, this trigger is hit.

138.title: Syntax
138.content: PLAYER_SPAWN Player_Name . | Player_Name : The string Display Name of any player. When specifying a player by name, use underscores instead of spaces, and do not use quotes; in this mode, you can also use asterisks as wildcards | .

139.title: Examples
139.content: // When any player spawns nearby PLAYER_SPAWN * // When Sir Pugger spawns nearby PLAYER_SPAWN Sir_Pugger .

142.title: PRAYER
142.content: Activates, deactivates, or toggles a prayer by name.

143.title: Syntax
143.content: PRAYER_NAME [0|1] . | PRAYER_NAME : The string name of a prayer. When specifying a prayer by name, use UPPERCASE with underscores instead of spaces, and do not use quotes. | 0 (Optional) : Force the named prayer OFF, regardless of its current state. | 1 (Optional) : Force the named prayer ON, regardless of its current state. | If no second parameter is specified, this command will toggle the named prayer to the opposite state. | .

144.title: Examples
144.content: // Always disable Protect from Melee PROTECT_FROM_MELEE 0 // Always enable Protect from Melee PROTECT_FROM_MELEE 1 // Toggle (reverse) the current state of Protect from Melee PROTECT_FROM_MELEE .

146.title: PROJECTILE
146.content: When projectile with the specified ID spawns, this trigger is hit.

147.title: Syntax
147.content: PROJECTILE Projectile_ID . | Projectile_ID : The integer ID of a projectile. | .

149.title: Notes
149.content: . | You can find a projectile ID by using Kittykeys -> Settings -> Print events to chat, or by using Dev tools -> Projectiles | .

151.title: QUICK_PRAYER
151.content: Activates, deactivates, or toggles the player’s previously defined quick prayers.

152.title: Syntax
152.content: QUICK_PRAYER [0|1] . | 0 (Optional) : Force the player’s quick prayers OFF, regardless of the current state. | 1 (Optional) : Force the player’s quick prayers ON, regardless of the current state. | If no parameter is specified, this command will toggle the player’s quick prayers to the opposite state. | .

153.title: Examples
153.content: // Always disable quick prayers QUICK_PRAYER 0 // Always enable quick prayers QUICK_PRAYER 1 // Toggle (reverse) the current state of quick prayers QUICK_PRAYER .

154.title: Notes
154.content: . | Requires quick prayers to be previously set. If there are no quick prayers configured, this command will do nothing. | .

156.title: SLEEP
156.content: Pauses the script for the given number of milliseconds, or for a random amount of time within the given range.

157.title: Syntax
157.content: SLEEP [Milliseconds|minMS] [maxMS] . | Milliseconds : If only a single parameter is supplied, the exact number of milliseconds to wait before continuing. | minMS : When two values are supplied to the sleep command, this is the minimum number of milliseconds that the script will pause before continuing. | maxMS : When two values are supplied to the sleep command, this is the maximum number of milliseconds that the script will pause before continuing. | .

158.title: Examples
158.content: // Wait exactly 750 milliseconds every time SLEEP 750 // Wait for some time between half a second and 1.5 seconds SLEEP 500 1500 .

159.title: Notes
159.content: . | 1000 ms == 1 second. 500ms == 0.5 seconds. | The average game tick is about 0.6 seconds (600ms), but this is not truly constant. Consider using the TICK command instead if your actions depend on accurate game ticks. | .

160.title: SOUND_EFFECT
160.content: When the specified sound effect starts, this trigger is hit.

161.title: Syntax
161.content: SOUND_EFFECT soundID . | soundID : The integer ID of a game sound. | .

162.title: Notes
162.content: Sound effects must be ON. The OSRS sound effects volume (the middle slider) must be set to at least 1% volume to use this trigger.

163.title: SPECIAL
163.content: Activates the special attack ability of the currently equipped weapon, if available.

164.title: Syntax
164.content: SPECIAL . | This command takes no arguments. | .

165.title: Examples
165.content: // Activate the special attack ability SPECIAL .

166.title: Notes
166.content: . | If the player’s equipped weapon has no special attack ability, this command will do nothing. | .

168.title: SPELL
168.content: Casts a magic spell on your current target, on an item or object by name, or enables left-click casting.

169.title: Syntax
169.content: SPELL_NAME 1|Item_Name|Item_ID|Game_Object_Name|Game_Object_ID . | 1 : Enables left-click casting for the specified spell. Lasts until the player switches weapons, or until another plugin changes this setting. | Item_Name : The string name of an item to cast the spell upon. When specifying items by name, use underscores instead of spaces, and do not use quotes; in this mode, you can also use asterisks as wildcards. | Item_ID : The integer ID of an item to cast the spell upon. | Game_Object_Name : The string name of a game object to cast the spell upon. When specifying items by name, use underscores instead of spaces, and do not use quotes; in this mode, you can also use asterisks as wildcards | Game_Object_ID : The integer ID of a game object to cast the spell upon. | .

170.title: Examples
170.content: // Enable left-click casting of Ice Barrage ICE_BARRAGE 1 // Cast high alchemy on all arrows in the player's inventory HIGH_LEVEL_ALCHEMY *arrows* // Automagically cast Fire Surge on the currently targeted NPC. FIRE_SURGE .

171.title: Notes
171.content: . | If the player does not have a target, this command will do nothing. See TARGET_SET for more information. | .

172.title: Demos
172.content: Left-click casting Fire Strike. Autocasting Fire Strike. High Level Alchemy.

173.title: STAT
173.content: When the specified stat of the player moves below the specified level, this trigger is hit.

174.title: Syntax
174.content: STAT Skill_Name Max_Level Min_Level . | Skill_Name : The string name of a skill, such as Attack or Herblore. | Max_Level : Trigger when the skill drops below this level. | Min_Level (Optional) : If specified, only trigger when the skill is between Max_Level and Min_level. | .

175.title: Examples
175.content: // Trigger if the player's HP drops below 50 STAT HITPOINTS 50 .

176.title: Notes
176.content: . | The order of Minimum and Maximum are reversed. | .

178.title: Syntax
178.content: TARGET [MenuAction] . | MenuAction (Optional) : The integer value _MenuAction can be if the desired action is not the default action for that NPC (i.e., if it is not the left-click action). | .

180.title: Notes
180.content: . | If the player does not have a target, this command will do nothing. See TARGET_SET for more information. | .

183.title: TARGET_SET
183.content: Sets the target to the specified NPC, regardless of closeness to the player.

184.title: Syntax
184.content: TARGET_SET . | This tcommand does not take any arguments. | Must be used with NPC_SPAWN. | .

185.title: Notes
185.content: . | Used to attack the specific spawn of an NPC (by ID) instead of the closest one. | .

186.title: TARGET_UNSET
186.content: Unsets the current target player or NPC.

189.title: Notes
189.content: . | If the player does not have a target, this command will do nothing. See TARGET_SET for more information. | .

191.title: TICK
191.content: This trigger hits once per game tick (approximately every 600ms).

193.title: Triggers in Kittykeys
193.content: Triggers are the heart of automatic scripts. Using trighgers, a series of commands can run automatically after some event happens in-game. Kittykeys supports the following triggers as documented below. If you have any questions, please join the JumpIfZero Plugins Discord server, and we’ll be happy to help! .

194.title: Supported Triggers
194.content: As of version 1.7.2, Kittykeys supports the following triggers: .

195.title: Triggers
195.content: Hey, Listen! . This wiki is not complete (yet). Please refer to the Help tab in the Kittykeys Editor, or to the JZ Plugins Discord server, for the most up-to-date information.

196.title: WALK_TARGET
196.content: Walks under your target’s current location.

198.title: Examples
198.content: // Walk under Hans, in Lumbridge TARGET_SET Hans WALK_TARGET .

199.title: Notes
199.content: . | If the player does not have a target, this command will do nothing. See TARGET_SET for more information. | .

201.title: WIDGET_SPAWN
201.content: When the specified widget spawns for the player, this trigger is hit.

202.title: Syntax
202.content: WIDGET_SPAWN Widget_ID . | Widget_ID : The integer ID of a game interface widget. | .

203.title: Examples
203.content: // Triggers when the player's bank opens WIDGET_SPAWN 12 .

204.title: Notes
204.content: . | Find Widget IDs by using Print events to chat in Kittykeys settings, or by using Dev Tools -> Widgets, | Useful for various skilling and bankstanding. | .

207.title: Syntax
207.content: WIELD Item_Name_1|Item_ID_1[,Item_Name_2|Item_ID_2,...] . | Item_Name : The string name of an item. When specifying items by name, use underscores instead of spaces, and do not use quotes; in this mode, you can also use asterisks as wildcards. | Item_ID : The integer ID of an item. | .

208.title: Examples
208.content: // Put on any mystic robe pieces in the inventory WIELD *mystic* .

209.title: Notes
209.content: . | Generally, you should prefer items’ integer IDs, as they are more precise. However, in certain situations, using the item’s name with a wildcard is required. | .

211.title: WITHDRAW
211.content: Withdraws the specified item(s) from your bank.

213.title: Examples
213.content: // Withdraw 7 water runes WITHDRAW water_rune 7 // Withdraw 7 water runes and 7 air runes WITHDRAW water_rune,air_rune 7 .

214.title: Notes
214.content: . | If multiple items are specifed, all will be withdrawn in the same quantity. Use multiple WITHDRAW commands to change the quantity of items. | . // BAD: This example would withdraw 6 logs and 6 tinderboxes WITHDRAW Oak_logs,Tinderbox 6 // GOOD: To change quantities, use another WITHDRAW command WITHDRAW Tinderbox 1 WITHDRAW Oak_logs 6 .

216.title: XP_DROP
216.content: When the player receives an XP drop of at least the specified amount, this trigger is hit.

217.title: Syntax
217.content: XP_DROP Skill_Name Amount . | Skill_Name (Optional) : | Amount : Integer minimum amount of XP in one drop that should activate the trigger. | .

218.title: Examples
218.content: // This triggers when the player earns 65 magic XP or higher in one action XP_DROP Magic 65 // This triggers when the player earns 50+ Runecraft XP in one action, but not 0-49 XP_DROP Runecraft 50 // This triggers when the player earns 100+ XP in one action, regardless of the skill XP_DROP 100 .

219.title: Notes
219.content: . | The skill name is Runecraft, not Runecrafting. | .
